Clustered Scheduling and Communication Pipelining For Efficient Resource Management Of Wireless Federated Learning

Cihat Keçeci, Mohammad Shaqfeh,  Fawaz Al-Qahtani,  Muhammad Ismail,  and Erchin Serpedin This publication was made possible by NPRP13S-0127-200182 from the Qatar National Research Fund (a member of Qatar Foundation). The statements made herein are solely the responsibility of the authors. (Corresponding author: Cihat Keçeci.)Cihat Keçeci and Erchin Serpedin are with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Texas A&M University, College Station, TX 77843, USA (e-mail: {kececi,eserpedin}@tamu.edu).Mohammad Shaqfeh is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Texas A&M University at Qatar, Doha, Qatar (e-mail: mohammad.shaqfeh@qatar.tamu.edu).Fawaz Al-Qahtani is with Qatar Foundation Research, Development and Innovation RDI, Doha, Qatar (e-mail: fawalqahtani@qf.org.qa).Muhammad Ismail is with the Department of Computer Science, Tennessee Tech University, Cookeville, TN 38505 USA (e-mail: mismail@tntech.edu).
Abstract

This paper proposes using communication pipelining to enhance the wireless spectrum utilization efficiency and convergence speed of federated learning in mobile edge computing applications. Due to limited wireless sub-channels, a subset of the total clients is scheduled in each iteration of federated learning algorithms. On the other hand, the scheduled clients wait for the slowest client to finish its computation. We propose to first cluster the clients based on the time they need per iteration to compute the local gradients of the federated learning model. Then, we schedule a mixture of clients from all clusters to send their local updates in a pipelined manner. In this way, instead of just waiting for the slower clients to finish their computation, more clients can participate in each iteration. While the time duration of a single iteration does not change, the proposed method can significantly reduce the number of required iterations to achieve a target accuracy. We provide a generic formulation for optimal client clustering under different settings, and we analytically derive an efficient algorithm for obtaining the optimal solution. We also provide numerical results to demonstrate the gains of the proposed method for different datasets and deep learning architectures.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, spectrum efficiency, communication pipelining, clustered scheduling, mobile edge computing

I Introduction

Federated learning is a promising distributed machine learning approach in which a central server (coordinator) and a number of data-holding clients cooperate in the training of a common machine learning model without exchanging data [1]. Only model parameters are shared and updated using an iterative gradient descent algorithm. Hence, learning from private clients’ data becomes possible while preserving the privacy of the clients’. Furthermore, federated learning enables achieving mutual benefits for all participating clients since training the algorithm using larger datasets by aggregating the private data of all participants leads to significant enhancements in the performance of data-hungry models. Moreover, federated learning enables better utilization of the distributed computational and storage resources. In particular, federated learning can be applied in mobile edge computing of wireless networks, e.g. [2, 3].

Research in federated learning has many aspects. One of them is exploring the variations among distributed gradient-descent training algorithms and analyzing the convergence performance of these algorithms with respect to the number of local and global iterations [4]. Another attractive research area is managing and optimizing the distributed computing and communication resources [5]. In particular, one of the main challenges in federated learning is the heterogeneity across the clients in terms of their computing and data resources. In this work, we focus on enhancing the utilization efficiency of wireless spectrum in federated learning. Consequently, enhancing the spectrum utilization leads to enhancing the prediction accuracy of the learning model at the end of the training process. Hence, achieving a target prediction accuracy becomes possible with a fewer number of iterations.

We propose using communication pipelining to enhance the spectrum utilization efficiency and speed up the convergence of federated learning. The primary motivation behind the proposed concept is that the computation time varies a lot between devices due to several reasons, such as different processor speeds or different sizes of the local dataset [6]. So, in an iterative gradient algorithm, the time of each iteration will be limited by the slowest client. To overcome this bottleneck, we propose that instead of just waiting for the slow clients to finish the computation of their local gradients, we can schedule an extra number of clients within the same iteration without requiring extra spectral bandwidth. A mixture of fast and slow clients should be scheduled in each iteration. The fast clients will use the spectrum first, while the slow clients are still running their computation of the local update. In this way, the number of clients who participate in each iteration can be increased while preserving the total duration of each iteration. So, the main idea is to cluster clients based on their computation time and then schedule a balanced mixture of clients from different clusters. The merit of this proposed concept is not necessarily in increasing the number of scheduled clients in each iteration but rather in allocating the wireless resources more efficiently. So, for example, fewer resources can be used while maintaining the number of clients per iteration. In principle, pipelining is an added degree of freedom in the resource allocation problem that can be adequately utilized to adjust the trade-off between allocated resources and the number of clients to be scheduled to achieve the best outcome of the federated learning process.

It is essential to highlight that the proposed concept of pipelined federated learning (PFL) is a general concept that can be applied to any variation of the gradient descent algorithm, whether batch or stochastic, and for both primal or dual optimization methods. In this paper, we just show, as an example, the formulation for a primal method with client sampling in each iteration and one local iteration of full-gradient (batch) computation in each global iteration. We refer to this method as Clustered-Scheduling Gradient-Descent (CS-GD). The extension of the concept to other cases, such as having more local iterations per client, is straightforward as long as the needed computation time per client is quantified.

I-A Related Work

The application of federated learning is discussed in several studies, such as [1, 7, 8, 9]. A seminal work on federated learning introducing the federated averaging algorithm is proposed in [1]. Federated averaging algorithm aggregates the updated local weights from each client in each global iteration. A comprehensive survey on federated learning is provided in [7, 8] by discussing the arising challenges, problems, and possible solutions regarding federated learning. The idea of federated learning is applied to the traffic prediction in [9].

In [10], the authors investigated the problem of client scheduling and resource block (RB) allocation to enhance the performance of model training using FL. In [11], the authors adopted FL in wireless networks as a resource allocation optimization problem that captures the trade-off between FL convergence wall clock time and energy consumption of UEs with heterogeneous computing and power resources. In [12], the authors proposed a novel over-the-air computation based-approach for fast global model aggregation via exploring the superposition property of a wireless multiple-access channel. This is achieved by joint device selection and beamforming design using the difference of convex function representation. In the same direction, the authors of [13] proposed a novel digital version of broadband over-the-air aggregation, called one-bit broadband digital aggregation (OBDA), featuring one-bit gradient quantization followed by digital quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM) at edge devices and over-the-air majority-voting based decoding at edge server.

Some other interesting works in the literature have considered the client scheduling problem, e.g. [14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19]. In [14], three practical scheduling policies, which are random scheduling, round Robin scheduling, and proportional fair scheduling, were compared. In [15], a probabilistic scheduling framework that considers both channel quality and local update importance was proposed. In [16], a multi-armed bandit-based framework was proposed for online client scheduling. In [17], scheduling based on a metric called “age of information” was proposed, and in [18], joint client scheduling and resource allocation was proposed. The training and wireless transmission parameters are jointly optimized in [20]. The works mentioned above do not take into consideration the variations in computational time among the clients. This is an essential factor to consider when scheduling the clients in order to avoid wasted time waiting for clients that need extended computing times. This is the main motivation for this work. The computational heterogeneity of the clients was considered in [19]. In this work, we develop the concept further by introducing client clustering and communication pipelining.

I-B Contributions

We have three major contributions in this paper, which are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We propose a novel federated learning concept PFL in which the communication for the model parameter updates is performed in a pipelined manner. The client updates in each round are pipelined by assigning the clients into clusters by their computation time.

  • •

    We investigate the problem of optimal client clustering in a generic form that can be applicable to all particular scenarios. We show how to formulate the problem, and then we present rigorous analytical steps to derive an optimal and efficient algorithm to solve the problem. The solutions steps involve the change of variables step, Lagrangian dual-problem formulation, manipulations of the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) necessary and sufficient conditions for optimality, hypothesis testing approach to find the active inequality constraints, and finally, an elegant geometric interpretation that helps in obtaining an efficient algorithm to solve the optimization problem.

  • •

    We demonstrate the advantages of the proposed PFL using extensive numerical examples for different federated learning tasks. We compare the gain introduced by the proposed pipelining scheme compared to the conventional federated learning scheme using the MNIST [21], the federated EMNIST [22], and the federated Shakespeare [1, 23] datasets by employing a variety neural network architectures such as multi-layer perceptron (MLP), convolutional neural network (CNN), and recurrent neural network (RNN). The simulation results suggest that employing PFL decreases the number of communication rounds required to train a deep neural network.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. The novel PFL scheme is introduced in Section II. A generic client clustering algorithm is proposed and solved in Section III. Extensive simulations are performed to validate the proposed method in Section IV. Finally, the conclusions are drawn in Section V. A summary of symbols and notations is provided in Table I.

II Pipelined Federated Learning (PFL)

A typical federated learning problem is considered with a total of M𝑀M clients participating in the optimization algorithm without sharing their own data sets. Each client has nmsubscript𝑛𝑚n_{m} data samples, where m𝑚m is the index of the client. The total number of data samples is n=∑m=1Mnm𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑛𝑚n=\sum_{m=1}^{M}n_{m}. The goal is to minimize a loss function defined as:

min𝐰∈ℝd⁡F​(𝐰)≡∑m=1Mpm​Fm​(𝐰)subscript𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑𝐹𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑝𝑚subscript𝐹𝑚𝐰\min_{\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F(\mathbf{w})\equiv\sum_{m=1}^{M}p_{m}F_{m}(\mathbf{w}) (1)

where pm=nmnsubscript𝑝𝑚subscript𝑛𝑚𝑛p_{m}=\frac{n_{m}}{n}, and

Fm​(𝐰)=1nm​∑i=1nml​(𝐰,𝐱mi,ymi)subscript𝐹𝑚𝐰1subscript𝑛𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑚𝑙𝐰superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑚𝑖F_{m}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{n_{m}}\sum_{i=1}^{n_{m}}l(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{x}_{m}^{i},y_{m}^{i}) (2)

where l​(𝐰,𝐱mi,ymi)𝑙𝐰superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑚𝑖l(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{x}_{m}^{i},y_{m}^{i}) is the loss function for the model and w𝑤w, 𝐱misuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑚𝑖\mathbf{x}_{m}^{i}, and ymisuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑚𝑖y_{m}^{i} are the model weights, the input values, and the output values, respectively.

The model training mechanism is based on a number T𝑇T of iterations. In each iteration t𝑡t, the server selects a sub-set of the total clients 𝒮​[t]𝒮delimited-[]𝑡\mathcal{S}[t] and broadcasts an updated model 𝐰​[t]𝐰delimited-[]𝑡\mathbf{w}[t] to the selected clients. The selected clients calculate the local gradient using their data samples and send the gradient to the server. A local gradient computation, at a given global round t𝑡t, is based on averaging the gradient of all data points in the data set of the client:

𝐠m​[t]=∇Fm​(𝐰​[t])=1nm​∑i=1nm∇l​(𝐰​[t],𝐱mi,ymi)subscript𝐠𝑚delimited-[]𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑚𝐰delimited-[]𝑡1subscript𝑛𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑚∇𝑙𝐰delimited-[]𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑚𝑖\mathbf{g}_{m}[t]=\nabla F_{m}(\mathbf{w}[t])=\frac{1}{n_{m}}\sum_{i=1}^{n_{m}}\nabla l(\mathbf{w}[t],\mathbf{x}_{m}^{i},y_{m}^{i}) (3)

Then the server averages the gradients

𝐠​[t]=∑m∈𝒮​[t]nm​𝐠m​[t]∑m∈𝒮​[t]nm𝐠delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑚𝒮delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑛𝑚subscript𝐠𝑚delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑚𝒮delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑛𝑚\mathbf{g}[t]=\frac{\sum_{m\in\mathcal{S}[t]}n_{m}\mathbf{g}_{m}[t]}{\sum_{m\in\mathcal{S}[t]}n_{m}} (4)

and updates the model according to:

𝐰​[t+1]=𝐰​[t]−ηt​𝐠​[t]𝐰delimited-[]𝑡1𝐰delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡𝐠delimited-[]𝑡\mathbf{w}[t+1]=\mathbf{w}[t]-\eta_{t}\mathbf{g}[t] (5)

where ηt>0subscript𝜂𝑡0\eta_{t}>0 is the learning rate in the t𝑡t-th iteration.

The uplink communication channel is considered to be an OFDM channel with a total of N𝑁N sub-channels. So, at a given time, no more than N𝑁N users can communicate with the server. Each sub-channel consists of multiple sub-carriers, and the data packets may cover multiple OFDM frames in order to fit the exchanged gradient data between the clients and the server. The number of gradients may be in the order of a million since the deep learning architectures usually have a large number of trainable variables. Furthermore, the total number of clients is assumed to be much larger than the number of sub-channels N≪Mmuch-less-than𝑁𝑀N\ll M. Therefore, the server should randomly select a subset of the clients at each iteration based on the available communication resources (i.e., the number of sub-channels).

The computation time to obtain the local gradients varies among the clients for several reasons, such as different processor speeds and different computation loads. Note that the computation load to calculate (3) depends on the total number of local data samples nmsubscript𝑛𝑚n_{m}. So, even if two clients have the same processor speed, a larger dataset will need a larger computation time than a client with a smaller dataset. This variation in computation time represents a practical consideration. On the other hand, since the packet size for communicating a local update to the server is the same across all clients (and it depends on the size of the gradient vector 𝐠𝐠\mathbf{g}), the communication time is considered to be the same for all clients. We know that wireless channels’ quality differs among different users due to small-scale and large-scale fading. So, some studies in the literature have taken the channel quality into consideration in the selection of the clients per iteration [14, 15]. However, in this work, we do not want to compromise machine learning best practices for other advantages related to opportunistic communication in order to enhance transmission data rate. Hence, we design a system that can give all clients an almost equal chance to be selected. In particular, we aim to use the largest possible amount of data in training by involving all clients and learning a model that is not biased towards the data of only a subset of the clients who get selected more frequently than others. In our communication scheme, we assume that the communication over the sub-channels applies a fixed rate that is independent of the particularly selected user. We assume that the fixed transmission rate can be reliably decoded by all users. This is a common scheme in practical communication systems. The wireless channel data rate efficiency could be enhanced by applying adaptive modulation and coding based on the channel conditions. However, this is out of the scope of this manuscript. We denote the computation time for client m𝑚m as τmsubscript𝜏𝑚\tau_{m}, the communication time of every client as τcomsubscript𝜏com\tau_{\text{com}}, and the combined time for the server to update the global model and broadcast it to the clients alongside information about the scheduled clients for next round as τserversubscript𝜏server\tau_{\text{server}}. In order for the server to update the global model and broadcast the new model 𝐰​[t]𝐰delimited-[]𝑡\mathbf{w}[t] to the clients, it must wait for all local updates. So, the bottleneck will be to wait for the slowest client until it finishes its local computation. Therefore, the duration of one global iteration t𝑡t is given as:

τglobal​[t]=τserver+maxm∈𝒮​[t]⁡τm+τcomsubscript𝜏globaldelimited-[]𝑡subscript𝜏serversubscript𝑚𝒮delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝜏𝑚subscript𝜏com\tau_{\text{global}}[t]=\tau_{\text{server}}+\max_{m\in\mathcal{S}[t]}\tau_{m}+\tau_{\text{com}} (6)

and the total time to complete the whole training process over T𝑇T iterations is given as:

τtotal=∑t=1Tτglobal​[t]=T​(τserver+τcom)+∑t=1Tmaxm∈𝒮​[t]⁡τmsubscript𝜏totalsuperscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝜏globaldelimited-[]𝑡𝑇subscript𝜏serversubscript𝜏comsuperscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝑚𝒮delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝜏𝑚\tau_{\text{total}}=\sum_{t=1}^{T}\tau_{\text{global}}[t]=T\left(\tau_{\text{server}}+\tau_{\text{com}}\right)+\sum_{t=1}^{T}\max_{m\in\mathcal{S}[t]}\tau_{m} (7)

One might think of excluding the clients with large values of τmsubscript𝜏𝑚\tau_{m} to speed up the training process. However, this is not a good option since those clients are likely to be the clients with the largest datasets, and hence, their local updates have higher weights (i.e., they have higher importance). Furthermore, it is advantageous to involve more data samples in the training process in order to enhance the overall learning accuracy. So, client exclusion is not recommended. Instead, client scheduling in each global iteration should be based on random sampling so that each client gets a chance to be involved in each global iteration. On the other hand, just waiting for the slowest client to finish its computation is a waste of the valuable spectral resources since the utilization efficiency ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon of the N𝑁N uplink sub-channels will be

ϵ=T​τcomτtotal≈τcomτcom+τserver+maxm⁡τmitalic-ϵ𝑇subscript𝜏comsubscript𝜏totalsubscript𝜏comsubscript𝜏comsubscript𝜏serversubscript𝑚subscript𝜏𝑚\epsilon=\frac{T\tau_{\text{com}}}{\tau_{\text{total}}}\approx\frac{\tau_{\text{com}}}{\tau_{\text{com}}+\tau_{\text{server}}+\max_{m}\tau_{m}} (8)

In this work, we propose to enhance the spectrum utilization without the need to exclude any client by scheduling a mixture of slow and fast clients in each iteration and making them use the available channels in a pipelined manner. So, the clients are grouped into a number K𝐾K of clusters based on their computation speed. More details about how to cluster the clients will be given in the next section. In each iteration, the server randomly samples N𝑁N clients from each cluster. In this way, the total number of clients per iteration will be K​N𝐾𝑁KN. The proposed PFL as illustrated in Fig. 1.

The utilization efficiency of the wireless sub-channels based on our proposal becomes:

ϵPFL=T​K​τcomτtotal≈K​τcomτcom+τserver+maxm⁡τm≈K​ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵPFL𝑇𝐾subscript𝜏comsubscript𝜏total𝐾subscript𝜏comsubscript𝜏comsubscript𝜏serversubscript𝑚subscript𝜏𝑚𝐾italic-ϵ\epsilon_{\text{PFL}}=\frac{TK\tau_{\text{com}}}{\tau_{\text{total}}}\approx\frac{K\tau_{\text{com}}}{\tau_{\text{com}}+\tau_{\text{server}}+\max_{m}\tau_{m}}\approx K\epsilon (9)

Thus, PFL does not only produce a significant increase in the utilization efficiency of the spectrum resources, but it does also improve the performance of the learning algorithm since adding more clients in each iteration will make it converge faster into the globally optimal solution of (1). So, while PFL does not decrease the time per iteration (6), it can help to achieve a targeted accuracy level for solving (1) with less number of iterations T𝑇T. So, it does indeed speed up the convergence performance of the learning algorithm. This will be demonstrated in the numerical examples section.

III Client Clustering

Clients are grouped into K𝐾K clusters, denoted as 𝒞1subscript𝒞1\mathcal{C}_{1}, 𝒞2subscript𝒞2\mathcal{C}_{2}, ⋯⋯\cdots, 𝒞Ksubscript𝒞𝐾\mathcal{C}_{K}. Each client is placed in just one cluster. So, ∑k=1K|𝒞k|=Msuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝒞𝑘𝑀\sum_{k=1}^{K}|\mathcal{C}_{k}|=M. The computation time for a given cluster k𝑘k is denoted as θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k}. This represents the time duration given to the selected clients in the cluster to complete their gradient computations. Then, they synchronously get scheduled to access the communication channels at time θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k}, for a communication duration τcomsubscript𝜏com\tau_{\text{com}}, as illustrated in Fig. 1.

Clustering the clients has some flexibility and it can be done in several ways. However, there are two strict constraints to be taken into consideration and two favorable, but not strict, requirements. First, all clients in a given cluster must satisfy the constraint that

τm≤θk,∀m∈𝒞k,k=1,…,K.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜏𝑚subscript𝜃𝑘formulae-sequencefor-all𝑚subscript𝒞𝑘𝑘1…𝐾\tau_{m}\leq\theta_{k},\quad\forall m\in\mathcal{C}_{k},\quad k=1,\dots,K. (10)

Furthermore, we have a constraint for scheduling the clusters into consequent communication frames. Assuming that the clusters are ordered in an ascending way based on their θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k}, the constraint is given as

θk−θk−1≥τcom,k=2,…,K.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝜃𝑘1subscript𝜏com𝑘2…𝐾\theta_{k}-\theta_{k-1}\geq\tau_{\text{com}},\quad k=2,\dots,K. (11)

A favorable, but not strict, requirement is to make the sizes of the clusters (i.e., number of clients) almost equal in order to give equal chance for all clients to participate in the training process. Hence, we have

|𝒞k|≈MK,∀k=1,…,K.formulae-sequencesubscript𝒞𝑘𝑀𝐾for-all𝑘1…𝐾|\mathcal{C}_{k}|\approx\frac{M}{K},\quad\forall k=1,\dots,K. (12)

Another favorable requirement is to satisfy that

|𝒞k|≥N,∀k=1,…,K,formulae-sequencesubscript𝒞𝑘𝑁for-all𝑘1…𝐾|\mathcal{C}_{k}|\geq N,\quad\forall k=1,\dots,K, (13)

in order to fully utilize the wireless resources to the maximum possible efficiency.

The Clustered-Scheduling Gradient-Descent (CS-GD) algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 1. This is a generic algorithm that can be applied for any arbitrary client clustering method given that (10) and (11) are satisfied. Next, we elaborate on the optimization of clustering based on (12) while maintaining the other two constraints in (10) and (11).

III-A Generic Optimization Problem Formulation

First, we sort the clients in ascending order of their computation time τmsubscript𝜏𝑚\tau_{m}, and assign the integer index Smsubscript𝑆𝑚S_{m} for the order of client m𝑚m. Hence, if Si>Sjsubscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑆𝑗S_{i}>S_{j}, then τi≥τj,∀Si,Sj∈{1,2,…,M}formulae-sequencesubscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝜏𝑗for-allsubscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑆𝑗12…𝑀\tau_{i}\geq\tau_{j},\forall S_{i},S_{j}\in\{1,2,\dots,M\}. Define the discrete function 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} for the ordered computation times of the clients as

𝒯​[Sm]=τm,Sm=1,2,…,M.formulae-sequence𝒯delimited-[]subscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝜏𝑚subscript𝑆𝑚12…𝑀\mathcal{T}[S_{m}]=\tau_{m},\quad S_{m}=1,2,\dots,M. (14)

By definition, 𝒯​[Sm]𝒯delimited-[]subscript𝑆𝑚\mathcal{T}[S_{m}] is monotonically non-decreasing. Here, we would like to provide a generic optimization framework for client clustering that is applicable for any arbitrary monotonically non-decreasing 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}. Extension into some special cases will be straightforward. An example of special cases is the case when the computation time is uniformly distributed among the clients between τminsubscript𝜏min\tau_{\text{min}} and τmaxsubscript𝜏max\tau_{\text{max}}, which results in

𝒯​[i]=τmin+τmax−τminM−1​(i−1),i∈{1,2,…,M}.formulae-sequence𝒯delimited-[]𝑖subscript𝜏minsubscript𝜏maxsubscript𝜏min𝑀1𝑖1𝑖12…𝑀\mathcal{T}[i]=\tau_{\text{min}}+\frac{\tau_{\text{max}}-\tau_{\text{min}}}{M-1}(i-1),\quad i\in\{1,2,\dots,M\}. (15)

Next, we use the notation ωksubscript𝜔𝑘\omega_{k} to denote the index Smsubscript𝑆𝑚S_{m} of the client that has the largest computation time among all clients in cluster 𝒞ksubscript𝒞𝑘\mathcal{C}_{k}. Hence, we have

ωk=maxm∈𝒞k⁡Sm,Sm∈{1,2,…,M}.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜔𝑘subscript𝑚subscript𝒞𝑘subscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝑆𝑚12…𝑀\omega_{k}=\max_{m\in\mathcal{C}_{k}}S_{m},\quad S_{m}\in\{1,2,\dots,M\}. (16)

Based on the introduced notations for sorting the clients by their computation time, clustering the clients will be based on the following rule:

𝒞k={m:ωk−1<Sm≤ωk},∀k∈{1,2,…,K},formulae-sequencesubscript𝒞𝑘conditional-set𝑚subscript𝜔𝑘1subscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝜔𝑘for-all𝑘12…𝐾\mathcal{C}_{k}=\{m~{}:~{}\omega_{k-1}<S_{m}\leq\omega_{k}\},\;\forall k\in\{1,2,\dots,K\}, (17)

where ωK=Msubscript𝜔𝐾𝑀\omega_{K}=M, and ω0=0subscript𝜔00\omega_{0}=0. Based on (17), it is straightforward to show that |Ck|=ωk−ωk−1subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝜔𝑘subscript𝜔𝑘1|C_{k}|=\omega_{k}-\omega_{k-1}. Now, we can formulate the optimization problem to reduce the variance among the number of clients per cluster since it is favorable to have clusters with almost equal sizes, according to (12)

minω1,…,ωK−1subscriptsubscript𝜔1…subscript𝜔𝐾1\displaystyle\min_{\omega_{1},\dots,\omega_{K-1}} ∑k=1K((ωk−ωk−1)−MK)2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑘subscript𝜔𝑘1𝑀𝐾2\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(\left(\omega_{k}-\omega_{k-1}\right)-\frac{M}{K}\right)^{2} (18a)
subject to 𝒯​[ωk]≤θk,∀k∈{1,2,…,K−1},formulae-sequence𝒯delimited-[]subscript𝜔𝑘subscript𝜃𝑘for-all𝑘12…𝐾1\displaystyle\mathcal{T}[\omega_{k}]\leq\theta_{k},\quad\forall k\in\{1,2,\dots,K-1\}, (18b)
ωK=M,subscript𝜔𝐾𝑀\displaystyle\omega_{K}=M, (18c)

where the constraint (18b) is based on (10). We do not need to include ωKsubscript𝜔𝐾\omega_{K} as an optimization variable, but rather we added it as a constraint in (18c) to enforce the optimal solution to include all clients in the clustering method and do not exclude any client.

Before we discuss the solution steps of (18), we will comment first on the selection of constrained thresholds θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} in (18b). First, introduce an extra hyper-parameter in the problem formulation to allow for some extra overall time that can be added at each global iteration. The added extra time is denoted by ΔglobalsubscriptΔglobal\Delta_{\text{global}}, where Δglobal≥0subscriptΔglobal0\Delta_{\text{global}}\geq 0. The purpose of this added hyper-parameter is to enable more flexibility in adjusting the number of clients per cluster and consequently to enable reducing the variations among the clusters’ sizes. Furthermore, the extra time ΔglobalsubscriptΔglobal\Delta_{\text{global}} can also be useful in enabling having a larger number of clusters K𝐾K if needed. However, there is a trade-off here since adding more time per iteration will reduce the spectrum utilization efficiency to become

ϵ=K​τcomτcom+τserver+max⁡τm+Δglobalitalic-ϵ𝐾subscript𝜏comsubscript𝜏comsubscript𝜏serversubscript𝜏𝑚subscriptΔglobal\epsilon=\frac{K\tau_{\text{com}}}{\tau_{\text{com}}+\tau_{\text{server}}+\max\tau_{m}+\Delta_{\text{global}}} (19)

We consider ΔglobalsubscriptΔglobal\Delta_{\text{global}} and the total number of clusters K𝐾K to be hyper-parameters that are set in advance before solving (18). The selection of ΔglobalsubscriptΔglobal\Delta_{\text{global}} will affect the values of the thresholds θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} in the optimization problem constraint (18b). We can start by examining θKsubscript𝜃𝐾\theta_{K} of the last cluster, i.e., the one with largest computation time, which can be adjusted as θK=τmax+Δglobalsubscript𝜃𝐾subscript𝜏maxsubscriptΔglobal\theta_{K}=\tau_{\text{max}}+\Delta_{\text{global}}, and then we apply (11) with equality to adjust θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} for clusters K−1𝐾1K-1, K−2𝐾2K-2, ⋯⋯\cdots, 111 sequentially. As a result, we will have

θk=τmax+Δglobal−(K−k)​τcom,k=K,…,1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝜏maxsubscriptΔglobal𝐾𝑘subscript𝜏com𝑘𝐾…1\theta_{k}=\tau_{\text{max}}+\Delta_{\text{global}}-(K-k)\tau_{\text{com}},\quad k=K,\dots,1. (20)

It should be noted that using the procedure mentioned above to adjust the values of the thresholds θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} in (20) aims at setting these thresholds at the maximum possible values in order to enlarge the space of feasible solutions of the main optimization problem (18), and hence, to enable achieving a lower value of the objective function (18a) at the optimal solution of the problem.

The upper bound of the possible number of clusters K𝐾K can be obtained by setting θ1≥τminsubscript𝜃1subscript𝜏min\theta_{1}\geq\tau_{\text{min}}, which can be simplified as τmax+Δglobal−(K−1)​τcom≥τminsubscript𝜏maxsubscriptΔglobal𝐾1subscript𝜏comsubscript𝜏min\tau_{\text{max}}+\Delta_{\text{global}}-(K-1)\tau_{\text{com}}\geq\tau_{\text{min}}. This inequality is equivalent to

K≤τmax−τmin+Δglobalτcom+1.𝐾subscript𝜏maxsubscript𝜏minsubscriptΔglobalsubscript𝜏com1K\leq\frac{\tau_{\text{max}}-\tau_{\text{min}}+\Delta_{\text{global}}}{\tau_{\text{com}}}+1.

Furthermore, since the number of clusters is an integer, we can write

K≤⌊τmax−τmin+τcom+Δglobalτcom⌋𝐾subscript𝜏maxsubscript𝜏minsubscript𝜏comsubscriptΔglobalsubscript𝜏comK\leq\Big{\lfloor}\frac{\tau_{\text{max}}-\tau_{\text{min}}+\tau_{\text{com}}+\Delta_{\text{global}}}{\tau_{\text{com}}}\Big{\rfloor} (21)

where ⌊x⌋𝑥\lfloor x\rfloor is the floor (rounding to highest lower integer) of x𝑥x.

The above upper bound of K𝐾K is theoretically correct. However, it is not plausible in practice since it is based on assuming θ1≥τminsubscript𝜃1subscript𝜏min\theta_{1}\geq\tau_{\text{min}} is satisfied at strict equality. This means that the first cluster will have just a single client that has the lowest computation time among all clients. This violates (12). Therefore, we alternatively prefer, from practical perspectives, to adjust K𝐾K by reducing the upper bound by one, which gives

K=⌊τmax−τmin+Δglobalτcom⌋.𝐾subscript𝜏maxsubscript𝜏minsubscriptΔglobalsubscript𝜏comK=\Big{\lfloor}\frac{\tau_{\text{max}}-\tau_{\text{min}}+\Delta_{\text{global}}}{\tau_{\text{com}}}\Big{\rfloor}. (22)

III-B Optimal Solution

It is not straightforward to solve the primal optimization problem in (18) analytically since the objective function will have non-linear terms after expanding the square in (18a). Therefore, we propose here a change of variable step to transform the problem formulation into a convex optimization problem. We use the number of clients per cluster |𝒞k|subscript𝒞𝑘|\mathcal{C}_{k}|, denoted as Mksubscript𝑀𝑘M_{k}, where k=1,2,…,K𝑘12…𝐾k=1,2,\dots,K, as the optimization variables instead of ωksubscript𝜔𝑘\omega_{k}. Thus, Mk=ωk−ωk−1subscript𝑀𝑘subscript𝜔𝑘subscript𝜔𝑘1M_{k}=\omega_{k}-\omega_{k-1}. Since the optimization variables Mksubscript𝑀𝑘M_{k} are integers, we relax the problem into the continuous domain by replacing Mksubscript𝑀𝑘M_{k} by δksubscript𝛿𝑘\delta_{k}, which is a real number. The resulting reformulated optimization problem will be

minδ1,…,δKsubscriptsubscript𝛿1…subscript𝛿𝐾\displaystyle\min_{\delta_{1},\dots,\delta_{K}} ∑k=1K(δk−MK)2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑘𝑀𝐾2\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(\delta_{k}-\frac{M}{K}\right)^{2} (23a)
subject to ∑i=1kδi≤πk,∀k∈{1,2,…,K−1},formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝛿𝑖subscript𝜋𝑘for-all𝑘12…𝐾1\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{k}\delta_{i}\leq\pi_{k},\quad\forall k\in\{1,2,\dots,K-1\}, (23b)
∑i=1Kδi=M.superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝛿𝑖𝑀\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{K}\delta_{i}=M. (23c)

where the thresholds πksubscript𝜋𝑘\pi_{k} satisfy πk=|{m:τm≤θk}|subscript𝜋𝑘conditional-set𝑚subscript𝜏𝑚subscript𝜃𝑘\pi_{k}=|\{m:\tau_{m}\leq\theta_{k}\}|, which can be equivalently written as

πk=max⁡Smsubject to ​𝒯​[Sm]≤θk.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝑆𝑚subject to 𝒯delimited-[]subscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝜃𝑘\pi_{k}=\max S_{m}\quad\text{subject to }\mathcal{T}[S_{m}]\leq\theta_{k}. (24)

By solving (23) for Mksubscript𝑀𝑘M_{k}, k=1,…,K𝑘1…𝐾k=1,\dots,K, we can then easily obtain ωk=∑i=1kMisubscript𝜔𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝑀𝑖\omega_{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{k}M_{i}, for k=1,…,K𝑘1…𝐾k=1,\dots,K. Then, we can apply clustering using (17). Problem (23) is a convex optimization problem and it can be solved analytically. After obtaining δksubscript𝛿𝑘\delta_{k}, k=1,…,K𝑘1…𝐾k=1,\dots,K, we can obtain Mksubscript𝑀𝑘M_{k} for k=1,…,K𝑘1…𝐾k=1,\dots,K by rounding to the nearest integer. We can also directly obtain ωksubscript𝜔𝑘\omega_{k} (k=1,…,K−1𝑘1…𝐾1k=1,\dots,K-1) of the primal optimization problem (18) by using

ωk=[∑i=1kδi],k=1,2,…,K−1,formulae-sequencesubscript𝜔𝑘delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝛿𝑖𝑘12…𝐾1\omega_{k}=\left[\sum_{i=1}^{k}\delta_{i}\right],\quad k=1,2,\dots,K-1,

where [x]delimited-[]𝑥[x] is the rounding operator to the nearest integer of x𝑥x. It should be noted that rounding to lowest higher integer should not cause any concern regarding violating the inequality constraints in (23b) or equivalently in (18b), since the thresholds πksubscript𝜋𝑘\pi_{k} in (23b) are by definition integers. So, if ∑i=1kδisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝛿𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{k}\delta_{i} is not an integer, rounding this summation to the lowest higher integer will also satisfy the constraint. When we obtain a relaxed (continuous-valued) number of clients per cluster, it is clear that the optimal value in the discrete domain should be by rounding the relaxed number of clients to the nearest integer. Any other value will give a higher variance. Furthermore, rounding to the lower or upper integer will give equal value. So, for example, if we have 7 users and want to distribute them into two groups. The optimal relaxed value will be 3.5 per group. If we round this value, we could have the first group has 4 and the second group has 3, or the first group has 3 and the second group has 4. Both solutions have exactly the same variance. So, in principle, rounding the nearest integer will always be optimal, although it may not be the unique optimal solution. The Lagrangian dual problem is given by

min\displaystyle\min\quad ℒ​(δ1,…,δK,λ1,…,λK−1,ν)ℒsubscript𝛿1…subscript𝛿𝐾subscript𝜆1…subscript𝜆𝐾1𝜈\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\delta_{1},\dots,\delta_{K},\lambda_{1},\dots,\lambda_{K-1},\nu) (25a)
subject to λi≥0,∀k∈{1,2,…,K−1},formulae-sequencesubscript𝜆𝑖0for-all𝑘12…𝐾1\displaystyle\lambda_{i}\geq 0,\quad\forall k\in\{1,2,\dots,K-1\}, (25b)

where the Lagrangian ℒℒ\mathcal{L} in (25a) can be written as

ℒ=∑k=1K(δk−MK)2+∑k=1K−1λk​(∑i=1kδi−πk)−ν​(∑i=1Kδi−M),ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑘𝑀𝐾2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1subscript𝜆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝛿𝑖subscript𝜋𝑘𝜈superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝛿𝑖𝑀\begin{split}\mathcal{L}=&\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(\delta_{k}-\frac{M}{K}\right)^{2}+\sum_{k=1}^{K-1}\lambda_{k}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{k}\delta_{i}-\pi_{k}\right)\\ &-\nu\left(\sum_{i=1}^{K}\delta_{i}-M\right),\end{split} (26)

where λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k} (k=1,…,K−1𝑘1…𝐾1k=1,\dots,K-1) are the dual variables associated with the inequality constraints of the primal problem (23b), and ν𝜈\nu is the dual variable associated with the equality constraint of the primal problem (23c).

Based on the KKT necessary and sufficient conditions for optimality [24], the optimal solution of our problem must satisfy the following:

  1. 1.

    The primal equality constraint (23c),

  2. 2.

    The primal inequality constraints in (23b), which are K−1𝐾1K-1 inequalities in total,

  3. 3.

    The dual constraints in (25b), which are also K−1𝐾1K-1 inequalities,

  4. 4.

    The complementary slackness, given by

    λk​(∑i=1kδi−πk)=0,∀k∈{1,2,…,K−1},formulae-sequencesubscript𝜆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝛿𝑖subscript𝜋𝑘0for-all𝑘12…𝐾1\lambda_{k}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{k}\delta_{i}-\pi_{k}\right)=0,\quad\forall k\in\{1,2,\dots,K-1\}, (27)

    which are K−1𝐾1K-1 equations related to the previous two conditions,

  5. 5.

    Vanishing of the gradient of the Lagrangian with respect to the primal optimization variables,

    ∂ℒ∂δk=0,∀k∈{1,2,…,K},formulae-sequenceℒsubscript𝛿𝑘0for-all𝑘12…𝐾\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\delta_{k}}=0,\quad\forall k\in\{1,2,\dots,K\}, (28)

    which gives K𝐾K equations in total.

Furthermore, since the problem is convex, the solution that satisfies all KKT conditions is unique. To solve this system of equations and equalities, we will first perform some analytical manipulations based on these conditions. Then, we will develop a hypothesis testing approach to get to the optimal solution in an efficient and quick way. Based on the KKT conditions, we can characterize the optimal solution as follows:

Lemma 1 (Primal Variables and Lagrangian Multipliers).

The optimal solution must satisfy

δk=δk−1+12​λk−1,∀k=2,…,K.formulae-sequencesubscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘112subscript𝜆𝑘1for-all𝑘2…𝐾\delta_{k}=\delta_{k-1}+\frac{1}{2}\lambda_{k-1},\quad\forall k=2,\dots,K. (29)
Proof:.

From (28) we obtain

∂ℒ∂δk=2​(δk−MK)+∑i=kK−1λi−ν=0,ℒsubscript𝛿𝑘2subscript𝛿𝑘𝑀𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑘𝐾1subscript𝜆𝑖𝜈0\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\delta_{k}}=2\left(\delta_{k}-\frac{M}{K}\right)+\sum_{i=k}^{K-1}\lambda_{i}-\nu=0,

which can be re-arranged to obtain

δk=MK−12​∑i=kK−1λi+12​ν,k=1,…,K.formulae-sequencesubscript𝛿𝑘𝑀𝐾12superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑘𝐾1subscript𝜆𝑖12𝜈𝑘1…𝐾\delta_{k}=\frac{M}{K}-\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=k}^{K-1}\lambda_{i}+\frac{1}{2}\nu,\quad k=1,\dots,K. (30)

Based on (30), and by evaluating δk−δk−1subscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘1\delta_{k}-\delta_{k-1}, we obtain (29). ∎

Lemma 2 (Ordered Subsequent Clusters).

The optimal solution must satisfy

δk≥δk−1,∀k=2,…,K.formulae-sequencesubscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘1for-all𝑘2…𝐾\delta_{k}\geq\delta_{k-1},\quad\forall k=2,\dots,K. (31)
Proof:.

This is a direct consequence of Lemma 1 since the Lagrangian multipliers λksubscript𝜆𝑘\lambda_{k} are non-negative based on the dual constraint (25b). ∎

Lemma 3 (Two Possibilities Per Complementary Slackness Condition).

The optimal solution must satisfy that either

δk=δk+1,subscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘1\displaystyle\delta_{k}=\delta_{k+1},\quad ifλk=0,∀k∈{1,2,…,K−1},formulae-sequenceifsubscript𝜆𝑘0for-all𝑘12…𝐾1\displaystyle\text{if}\quad\lambda_{k}=0,\quad\forall k\in\{1,2,\dots,K-1\}, (32a)
or
δk=πk−∑i=1k−1δi,subscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘1subscript𝛿𝑖\displaystyle\delta_{k}=\pi_{k}-\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\delta_{i},\quad ifλk>0,∀k∈{1,2,…,K−1}.formulae-sequenceifsubscript𝜆𝑘0for-all𝑘12…𝐾1\displaystyle\text{if}\quad\lambda_{k}>0,\quad\forall k\in\{1,2,\dots,K-1\}. (32b)
Proof:.

From the complementary slackness conditions in (27), the optimal solution must satisfy that either λk=0subscript𝜆𝑘0\lambda_{k}=0, which results in (32a) by substituting for λk=0subscript𝜆𝑘0\lambda_{k}=0 in (29), or ∑i=1kδi−πk=0superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝛿𝑖subscript𝜋𝑘0\sum_{i=1}^{k}\delta_{i}-\pi_{k}=0, which can be re-arranged as in (32b). These two possibilities correspond to satisfying the primal inequality constraints in (23b) at strict inequality in the first case or strict equality in the second case. The primal constraint in the latter case can be described as “active”. ∎

III-C Hypothesis Testing Approach

The main bottleneck in solving (25) using the KKT conditions is that we cannot know in advance which inequality constraints will be active and which ones will be inactive at the optimal solution. All possibilities are likely in the generic problem formulation in which the thresholds πksubscript𝜋𝑘\pi_{k} (k=1,…,K−1𝑘1…𝐾1k=1,\dots,K-1) can take any arbitrary ordered values. So, to overcome this bottleneck, we propose a hypothesis-testing approach to solve the KKT conditions. We can start by guessing which inequality constraints in (23b) will be active and which ones will be inactive. This will be a hypothesis that will be tested for validity. Based on the initial assumption of the hypothesis, we can then obtain all primal optimization variables δksubscript𝛿𝑘\delta_{k} (k=1,2,…,K𝑘12…𝐾k=1,2,\dots,K) based on (32a) and (32b) of Lemma 3, in addition to (23c). We will have K𝐾K independent equations and K𝐾K variables, so the solution of this system of equations will be unique. After we obtain the solution, we can check for the validity of the hypothesis by examining two things. First, we check that there is no contradiction in the hypothesis’s initial assumption by examining if all primal inequality constraints that were assumed to be inactive are indeed inactive after we substitute the obtained values of δksubscript𝛿𝑘\delta_{k} (k=1,2,…,K𝑘12…𝐾k=1,2,\dots,K). Second, we check if the obtained δksubscript𝛿𝑘\delta_{k} (k=1,2,…,K𝑘12…𝐾k=1,2,\dots,K) satisfy (31) of Lemma 2. This check is for the optimality of the solution since the result in Lemma 2 is based on manipulations of the last KKT condition about vanishing gradient of the Lagrangian. So, in summary, we need to make sure that the hypothesis is both (i) non-contradicting and (ii) generating the unique optimal solution of the problem.

Since we have in total K−1𝐾1K-1 inequality constraints in (23b), we can have a maximum of 2K−1superscript2𝐾12^{K-1} hypotheses to be tested. In a practical deployment scenario, the number of clusters K𝐾K is assumed to be limited to a single-digit number. So, checking all possible hypotheses would not be a prohibitively expensive step in such scenarios. Having said that, we also propose a search algorithm to find the correct hypothesis quickly. This can be particularly useful for scenarios of large K𝐾K. However, before discussing the search algorithm, we will give numerical examples of hypothesis testing to clarify the concept. Then, we will formulate the hypothesis testing procedure in a systematic way that can be implemented in an algorithm.

Example 1 (Three Scenarios of Hypothesis Testing).

Assume that K=4𝐾4K=4, M=100𝑀100M=100, π1=10subscript𝜋110\pi_{1}=10, π2=46subscript𝜋246\pi_{2}=46, and π3=80subscript𝜋380\pi_{3}=80. We can distinguish between three cases:

  • •

    Case A: Assuming that only the second inequality constraint is active is a contradicting hypothesis.

  • •

    Case B: Assuming that only the first and second inequality constraints are active is a non-contradicting but not an optimal hypothesis.

  • •

    Case C: Assuming that only the first inequality constraint is active is both a non-contradicting and optimal hypothesis.

In Case A, since the second inequality constraint is assumed to be active, we should use (32b) for k=2𝑘2k=2, and use (32a) for k=1𝑘1k=1 and k=3𝑘3k=3. The system of four equations that should be solved is given as:

δ1subscript𝛿1\displaystyle\delta_{1} =δ2,absentsubscript𝛿2\displaystyle=\delta_{2}, (33a)
δ2subscript𝛿2\displaystyle\delta_{2} =π2−δ1,absentsubscript𝜋2subscript𝛿1\displaystyle=\pi_{2}-\delta_{1}, (33b)
δ3subscript𝛿3\displaystyle\delta_{3} =δ4,absentsubscript𝛿4\displaystyle=\delta_{4}, (33c)
δ4subscript𝛿4\displaystyle\delta_{4} =M−(δ1+δ2+δ3).absent𝑀subscript𝛿1subscript𝛿2subscript𝛿3\displaystyle=M-(\delta_{1}+\delta_{2}+\delta_{3}). (33d)

The numerical solution of these equations yields δ1=δ2=23subscript𝛿1subscript𝛿223\delta_{1}=\delta_{2}=23, and δ3=δ4=27subscript𝛿3subscript𝛿427\delta_{3}=\delta_{4}=27. By checking the first inequality constraint, we will find a contradiction since δ1=23>π1=10subscript𝛿123subscript𝜋110\delta_{1}=23>\pi_{1}=10. So, this is a contradicting hypothesis.

In Case B, we will have the same system of equations (33), but with replacing (33a) by δ1=π1subscript𝛿1subscript𝜋1\delta_{1}=\pi_{1}. The solution of the system of four equations in this case yields δ1=10subscript𝛿110\delta_{1}=10, δ2=36subscript𝛿236\delta_{2}=36, and δ3=δ4=27subscript𝛿3subscript𝛿427\delta_{3}=\delta_{4}=27. By checking for all inequality constraints, we do not find any contradiction. However, this solution is not optimal since δ2=36>δ3=27subscript𝛿236subscript𝛿327\delta_{2}=36>\delta_{3}=27, and this violates the optimality condition (31) that was proven in Lemma 2.

Finally, in Case C, we will have (33a) replaced by δ1=π1subscript𝛿1subscript𝜋1\delta_{1}=\pi_{1}, and (33b) replaced by δ2=δ3subscript𝛿2subscript𝛿3\delta_{2}=\delta_{3}. The other two equations will be the same. The solution in this case yields δ1=10subscript𝛿110\delta_{1}=10, and δ2=δ3=δ4=30subscript𝛿2subscript𝛿3subscript𝛿430\delta_{2}=\delta_{3}=\delta_{4}=30. This solution does not violate any inequality constraint and satisfies the optimality check in (31). So, it is the optimal solution of the problem.

To formulate the hypothesis testing approach in a systematic algorithm, we use the notation 𝐡𝐡\mathbf{h} for a binary vector of K𝐾K entries that indicates which primal inequality constraints are assumed to be active by the hypothesis. The final entry in 𝐡𝐡\mathbf{h} is for the equality constraint (23c), which is by definition always active. The entry of 𝐡𝐡\mathbf{h} that corresponds to the index k𝑘k of an active constraint is given the value 111, and the entry that corresponds to the index of an inactive inequality is given the value 00. So, for Case A in the previous example we have 𝐡=(0,1,0,1)𝐡0101\mathbf{h}=(0,1,0,1). For Case B, we have 𝐡=(1,1,0,1)𝐡1101\mathbf{h}=(1,1,0,1), and for Case C, we have 𝐡=(1,0,0,1)𝐡1001\mathbf{h}=(1,0,0,1).

We also use the notation 𝐩​(𝐡)𝐩𝐡\mathbf{p}(\mathbf{h}) for a vector that is obtained from 𝐡𝐡\mathbf{h} by indicating the indices of the entries that have value 111. So, in our previous examples, if 𝐡=(0,1,0,1)𝐡0101\mathbf{h}=(0,1,0,1), then 𝐩=(2,4)𝐩24\mathbf{p}=(2,4), and if 𝐡=(1,1,0,1)𝐡1101\mathbf{h}=(1,1,0,1), then 𝐩=(1,2,4)𝐩124\mathbf{p}=(1,2,4), and if 𝐡=(1,0,0,1)𝐡1001\mathbf{h}=(1,0,0,1), then 𝐩=(1,4)𝐩14\mathbf{p}=(1,4), and so on. It should be noted that while the number of entries of 𝐡𝐡\mathbf{h} is fixed at K𝐾K, the number of entries in 𝐩​(𝐡)𝐩𝐡\mathbf{p}(\mathbf{h}) varies depending on the sum of all entries of the hypothesis 𝐡𝐡\mathbf{h}. Furthermore, we use the notation 𝐩(i)superscript𝐩𝑖\mathbf{p}^{(i)} to indicate the i-th entry of 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p}. So, for example, if 𝐩=(1,2,4)𝐩124\mathbf{p}=(1,2,4), then 𝐩(1)=1superscript𝐩11\mathbf{p}^{(1)}=1, 𝐩(2)=2superscript𝐩22\mathbf{p}^{(2)}=2 and 𝐩(3)=4superscript𝐩34\mathbf{p}^{(3)}=4.

Based on the introduced notations for 𝐡𝐡\mathbf{h} and 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p}, we can obtain that for a given hypothesis 𝐡𝐡\mathbf{h}, the resulting system of equations to obtain δksubscript𝛿𝑘\delta_{k}, k=1,…,K𝑘1…𝐾k=1,\dots,K, will have the following generalized formula to obtain the solution for any 𝐩​(𝐡)𝐩𝐡\mathbf{p}(\mathbf{h}):

δi=π𝐩(j)−π𝐩(j−1)𝐩(j)−𝐩(j−1),∀i∈{𝐩(j−1)+1,…,𝐩(j)},formulae-sequencesubscript𝛿𝑖subscript𝜋superscript𝐩𝑗subscript𝜋superscript𝐩𝑗1superscript𝐩𝑗superscript𝐩𝑗1for-all𝑖superscript𝐩𝑗11…superscript𝐩𝑗\delta_{i}=\frac{\pi_{\mathbf{p}^{(j)}}-\pi_{\mathbf{p}^{(j-1)}}}{\mathbf{p}^{(j)}-\mathbf{p}^{(j-1)}},\quad\forall i\in\left\{\mathbf{p}^{(j-1)}+1,\dots,\mathbf{p}^{(j)}\right\}, (34)

where j=1,2,…,|𝐩|𝑗12…𝐩j=1,2,\dots,|\mathbf{p}|, 𝐩(0)=0superscript𝐩00\mathbf{p}^{(0)}=0, π0=0subscript𝜋00\pi_{0}=0 and πK=Msubscript𝜋𝐾𝑀\pi_{K}=M. Implementing (34) in an algorithm is straightforward by running a for-loop for the values of j𝑗j, and obtaining all δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i}’s that are associated with j𝑗j in (34). After running through all j𝑗j values, all δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i}, i=1,…,K𝑖1…𝐾i=1,\dots,K will be obtained.

III-D Quick Search Over Space Of Possible Hypotheses

To be able to find the non-contradicting and optimal hypothesis in the minimum number of steps, we need to make some theoretical characterization of the space of possible hypotheses so that we can exclude many possibilities directly and find the optimal solution in a quick search.

Theorem 1 (Inactive Primal Constraints).

If πksubscript𝜋𝑘\pi_{k} in the k𝑘k-th inequality constraint in (23b) satisfies

πk>kK​M,k∈{1,2,…,K−1},formulae-sequencesubscript𝜋𝑘𝑘𝐾𝑀𝑘12…𝐾1\pi_{k}>\frac{k}{K}M,\quad k\in\{1,2,\dots,K-1\}, (35)

then this constraint will be inactive at the optimal solution of the problem.

Proof:.

Assume that (35) is true and the k𝑘k-th inequality constraint is active. The latter means

∑i=1kδi=πk.superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝛿𝑖subscript𝜋𝑘\sum_{i=1}^{k}\delta_{i}=\pi_{k}. (36)

If the solution is optimal, then we must have (31) satisfied as proven in Lemma 2. Thus, we must have δk≥δk−1≥⋯≥δ1subscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘1⋯subscript𝛿1\delta_{k}\geq\delta_{k-1}\geq\dots\geq\delta_{1}. Consequently, we must have that δk≥πkksubscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘𝑘\delta_{k}\geq\frac{\pi_{k}}{k}, which can be bounded based on (35) to have

δk≥πkk>MK.subscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘𝑘𝑀𝐾\delta_{k}\geq\frac{\pi_{k}}{k}>\frac{M}{K}. (37)

Furthermore, by simple manipulations of the equality constraint in (23c) with (36), we obtain

∑i=k+1Kδi=M−πk.superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛿𝑖𝑀subscript𝜋𝑘\sum_{i=k+1}^{K}\delta_{i}=M-\pi_{k}. (38)

If the solution is optimal, then we must have (31) satisfied, which yields δK≥δK−1≥⋯≥δk+1subscript𝛿𝐾subscript𝛿𝐾1⋯subscript𝛿𝑘1\delta_{K}\geq\delta_{K-1}\geq\dots\geq\delta_{k+1}. Consequently, we must have δk+1≤M−πkK−ksubscript𝛿𝑘1𝑀subscript𝜋𝑘𝐾𝑘\delta_{k+1}\leq\frac{M-\pi_{k}}{K-k}, which can be bounded based on (35) to have

δk+1≤M−πkK−k<M−kK​MK−k=M​(K−kK)K−k=MK.subscript𝛿𝑘1𝑀subscript𝜋𝑘𝐾𝑘𝑀𝑘𝐾𝑀𝐾𝑘𝑀𝐾𝑘𝐾𝐾𝑘𝑀𝐾\delta_{k+1}\leq\frac{M-\pi_{k}}{K-k}<\frac{M-\frac{k}{K}M}{K-k}=\frac{M\left(\frac{K-k}{K}\right)}{K-k}=\frac{M}{K}. (39)

From (37) and (39), we find that δk>MK>δk+1subscript𝛿𝑘𝑀𝐾subscript𝛿𝑘1\delta_{k}>\frac{M}{K}>\delta_{k+1}. However, based on the optimality check in (31), we must have δk+1≥δksubscript𝛿𝑘1subscript𝛿𝑘\delta_{k+1}\geq\delta_{k}. So, there is a contradiction. Thus, if (35) is true, then the associated constraint must be inactive at optimality. ∎

The statement in Theorem 1 can help in excluding many hypotheses directly from the search algorithm. Furthermore, we can narrow the space of possible hypotheses even further based on the following theorem.

Theorem 2 (Generalized Check For Inactive Primal Constraints).

Assume that we have any arbitrary two integers a𝑎a and b𝑏b such that 1≤a<b≤K1𝑎𝑏𝐾1\leq a<b\leq K. If πksubscript𝜋𝑘\pi_{k} associated with the k𝑘k-th inequality constraint in (23b) satisfies

πk−πak−a>πb−πab−a,k∈{a+1,a+2,…,b−1},formulae-sequencesubscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝜋𝑎𝑘𝑎subscript𝜋𝑏subscript𝜋𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑘𝑎1𝑎2…𝑏1\frac{\pi_{k}-\pi_{a}}{k-a}>\frac{\pi_{b}-\pi_{a}}{b-a},\quad k\in\{a+1,a+2,\dots,b-1\}, (40)

then this constraint will be inactive at the optimal solution of the problem.

Before presenting the proof, it should be noted that the statement in Theorem 2 is a generalized version of the statement in Theorem 1. The latter is a special case in which we have a=0𝑎0a=0 and b=K𝑏𝐾b=K, and similar to (34), we use the notation π0=0subscript𝜋00\pi_{0}=0 and πK=Msubscript𝜋𝐾𝑀\pi_{K}=M.

Proof:.

Assume that both (40) is true and the k𝑘k-th inequality constraint is active. The latter means that (36) and (38) are true as discussed in the proof of Theorem 1. Furthermore, we need to use the a𝑎a-th and the b𝑏b-th primal constraints in the construction of the proof. So, we have

∑i=1aδisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑎subscript𝛿𝑖\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{a}\delta_{i} ≤πa,absentsubscript𝜋𝑎\displaystyle\leq\pi_{a}, (41a)
∑i=1bδisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑏subscript𝛿𝑖\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{b}\delta_{i} ≤πb.absentsubscript𝜋𝑏\displaystyle\leq\pi_{b}. (41b)

By simple manipulations of (36) and (41a), we obtain that ∑i=a+1kδi≥πk−πasuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑎1𝑘subscript𝛿𝑖subscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝜋𝑎\sum_{i=a+1}^{k}\delta_{i}\geq\pi_{k}-\pi_{a}. Furthermore, if the solution is optimal, then we must have (31) satisfied. Thus, we must have δk≥δk−1≥⋯≥δa+1subscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝛿𝑘1⋯subscript𝛿𝑎1\delta_{k}\geq\delta_{k-1}\geq\dots\geq\delta_{a+1}. Consequently, we must have that δk≥πk−πak−asubscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝜋𝑎𝑘𝑎\delta_{k}\geq\frac{\pi_{k}-\pi_{a}}{k-a}, which can be bounded based on (40) to have

δk≥πk−πak−a>πb−πab−a.subscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝜋𝑎𝑘𝑎subscript𝜋𝑏subscript𝜋𝑎𝑏𝑎\delta_{k}\geq\frac{\pi_{k}-\pi_{a}}{k-a}>\frac{\pi_{b}-\pi_{a}}{b-a}. (42)

Next, we can do simple manipulations on the equality constraint in (23c) with (41b) to obtain that ∑i=b+1Kδi≥M−πbsuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑏1𝐾subscript𝛿𝑖𝑀subscript𝜋𝑏\sum_{i=b+1}^{K}\delta_{i}\geq M-\pi_{b}, which can be combined with (38) to obtain ∑i=k+1bδi≤(M−πk)−(M−πb)=πb−πksuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑘1𝑏subscript𝛿𝑖𝑀subscript𝜋𝑘𝑀subscript𝜋𝑏subscript𝜋𝑏subscript𝜋𝑘\sum_{i=k+1}^{b}\delta_{i}\leq(M-\pi_{k})-(M-\pi_{b})=\pi_{b}-\pi_{k}. Moreover, if the solution is optimal, then we must have (31) satisfied, which yields δb≥δb−1≥⋯≥δk+1subscript𝛿𝑏subscript𝛿𝑏1⋯subscript𝛿𝑘1\delta_{b}\geq\delta_{b-1}\geq\dots\geq\delta_{k+1}. Consequently, we must have that

δk+1≤πb−πkb−k.subscript𝛿𝑘1subscript𝜋𝑏subscript𝜋𝑘𝑏𝑘\delta_{k+1}\leq\frac{\pi_{b}-\pi_{k}}{b-k}. (43)

Looking back at (40), we can re-write the inequality as πk>πa+k−ab−a​(πb−πa)subscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝜋𝑎𝑘𝑎𝑏𝑎subscript𝜋𝑏subscript𝜋𝑎\pi_{k}>\pi_{a}+\frac{k-a}{b-a}(\pi_{b}-\pi_{a}), which can be used to bound (43) as follows

δk+1subscript𝛿𝑘1\displaystyle\delta_{k+1} ≤πb−πkb−kabsentsubscript𝜋𝑏subscript𝜋𝑘𝑏𝑘\displaystyle\leq\frac{\pi_{b}-\pi_{k}}{b-k}
<πb−πa−k−ab−a​(πb−πa)b−kabsentsubscript𝜋𝑏subscript𝜋𝑎𝑘𝑎𝑏𝑎subscript𝜋𝑏subscript𝜋𝑎𝑏𝑘\displaystyle<\frac{\pi_{b}-\pi_{a}-\frac{k-a}{b-a}(\pi_{b}-\pi_{a})}{b-k}
=(πb−πa)​(1−k−ab−a)b−kabsentsubscript𝜋𝑏subscript𝜋𝑎1𝑘𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑏𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{(\pi_{b}-\pi_{a})\left(1-\frac{k-a}{b-a}\right)}{b-k}
=πb−πab−aabsentsubscript𝜋𝑏subscript𝜋𝑎𝑏𝑎\displaystyle=\frac{\pi_{b}-\pi_{a}}{b-a} (44)

From (42) and (44), we find that δk>πb−πab−a>δk+1subscript𝛿𝑘subscript𝜋𝑏subscript𝜋𝑎𝑏𝑎subscript𝛿𝑘1\delta_{k}>\frac{\pi_{b}-\pi_{a}}{b-a}>\delta_{k+1}. However, based on the optimality check in (31), we must have δk+1≥δksubscript𝛿𝑘1subscript𝛿𝑘\delta_{k+1}\geq\delta_{k}. So, there is a contradiction. Thus, if (40) is true, then the associated constraint must be inactive at optimality. ∎

Actually, we can adopt a geometric interpretation of Theorem 2 as shown in Fig. 2, since the left term of the inequality in (40) is the slope of the line connecting the two points (a,πa)𝑎subscript𝜋𝑎(a,\pi_{a}) and (k,πk)𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘(k,\pi_{k}), while the right term is the slope of the line connecting the two points (a,πa)𝑎subscript𝜋𝑎(a,\pi_{a}) and (b,πb)𝑏subscript𝜋𝑏(b,\pi_{b}). Thus, we can equivalently reinterpret Theorem 2 as stating that the k𝑘k-th inequality constraint will be inactive at the optimal solution if the point (k,πk)𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘(k,\pi_{k}) is located above the line segment that connects the two points (a,πa)𝑎subscript𝜋𝑎(a,\pi_{a}) and (b,πb)𝑏subscript𝜋𝑏(b,\pi_{b}). This statement is true for any value of a<k𝑎𝑘a<k and any value of b>k𝑏𝑘b>k. Hence, we can establish a nice geometric interpretation of our problem. Actually, finding the active inequality constraints can be interpreted as finding the lower convex hull in a two-dimensional Cartesian coordinate system for the set of inequality thresholds, represented as:

𝒫={(k,πk):k=0,1,…,K}.𝒫conditional-set𝑘subscript𝜋𝑘𝑘01…𝐾\mathcal{P}=\{(k,\pi_{k}):k=0,1,\dots,K\}. (45)

Furthermore, the active constraints are only those that are located on the vertices of the piecewise linear boundary of the lower convex hull of 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}, as illustrated in Fig. 3, which shows a numerical example of 𝒫={(0,0),(1,10),(2,46),(3,80),(4,100)}𝒫001102463804100\mathcal{P}=\{(0,0),(1,10),(2,46),(3,80),(4,100)\}. This particular 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} is related to the previously discussed Example 1. As shown in Fig. 3, the point (1,10)110(1,10) is a vertex in the boundary of the lower convex hull of 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}, while the points (2,46)246(2,46) and (3,80)380(3,80) are not located on the boundary of the lower convex hull. Thus, the first constraint should be active at the optimal solution, while the second and third constraints should be inactive. This conclusion was already verified in Example 1. So, the geometric interpretation is consistent with the analytical algebraic derivations.

The significance of the geometric interpretation is that it enables us to define an efficient and quick procedure to find the optimal solution by searching for the boundary of the lower convex hull of 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} of our problem. This can be done sequentially segment-by-segment starting from the lower-left corner point (0,0)00(0,0) until we reach the upper right corner point (K,M)𝐾𝑀(K,M), as summarized in Algorithm 2.

IV Performance Analysis and Comparison

In this section, as a numerical example, we compare the performance of a conventional federated learning scheme (in which N𝑁N clients are randomly selected per iteration t𝑡t regardless of their number of data samples) with our suggested PFL scheme (which follows Algorithm 1 and the solution in Algorithm 2). We analyze the proposed PFL method using different datasets such as the MNIST [21], the federated EMNIST [22], and the federated Shakespeare [1, 23] datasets and neural network architectures such as MLP, CNN, and RNN to cover a wide range of federated learning applications from the literature. We used Python programming language and Tensorflow Federated framework [25] for the simulations.

Without loss of generality, we assume a scenario in which all clients have similar processors’ speeds, and the variation in computation time τmsubscript𝜏𝑚\tau_{m} is solely dependent on the number of data sample per client, i.e., τm=σ​nmsubscript𝜏𝑚𝜎subscript𝑛𝑚\tau_{m}=\sigma n_{m}, where σ𝜎\sigma is the computation time per data sample.

IV-A MNIST Dataset

First, we have validated the proposed method using the MNIST dataset [21], which consists of hand-written digits. In the simulation scenario, we assumed that there are M=1500𝑀1500M=1500 clients. We assumed that the number of data samples (i.e., images of hand-written digits) per client nmsubscript𝑛𝑚n_{m} is uniformly distributed between nmin=10subscript𝑛10n_{\min}=10 samples and nmax=70subscript𝑛70n_{\max}=70 samples. We compared the results of PFL to the conventional federated learning scheme where there is only one cluster. We considered four possible scenarios for the ratio between the variation in computation time to communication time in (22). We performed the simulations for 111, 222, 333, and 444 clusters, respectively. We also studied the effect of the number of sub-channels on the performance of PFL. Hence, we varied the number of sub-channels as 111, 222, 444, and 888, respectively. Each sub-channel can be used by a single client only at a given time instant. We used two different deep learning models for the training of the MNIST dataset. The first model is a two-layer CNN model with 323232 and 646464 5×5555\times 5 filters, respectively. The second model is an MLP model with two layers with 200200200 nodes in each layer. We run the training algorithm for up to 100010001000 rounds of global model (server) updates. We obtained the model prediction accuracy by testing the trained model on a separate test dataset as a function of the number of communication rounds. The batch size is chosen as 161616, and the number of local epochs is set to 111. The client learning rate is optimized using a multiplicative parameter grid, and the server learning rate (the scaling factor) is set to 111. The number of required rounds to reach 97%percent9797\% accuracy for the CNN model trained on the MNIST dataset is shown in Table II. Similarly, the number of required rounds to reach 96%percent9696\% accuracy for the MLP model trained on the MNIST dataset is shown in Table III.

As seen in Table II and Table III, applying clustered scheduling enables achieving faster convergence (in terms of the number of iterations) in comparison with a baseline federated learning approach with no clustering. The conventional federated learning scheme with the CNN model achieves 97%percent9797\% accuracy in 273273273, 180180180, 152152152, and 118118118 rounds with 111, 222, 444, and 888 sub-channels, respectively. The proposed PFL scheme provides 32%percent3232\% gain compared to the conventional federated learning scheme in terms of required rounds by employing only 222 clusters. The gain provided by clustering is improved for each additional cluster in the system. The marginal gain provided by the PFL scheme decreases with the increasing number of sub-channels since the effective number of data samples per communication round is already enough for the conventional federated learning.

The benefit of the proposed clustered pipelining scheme can be realized in a different way by decreasing the bandwidth requirements. Thus, we can decrease the number of sub-channels needed to achieve the desired accuracy value. For instance, by using 444 clusters with 111 sub-channel, we reach the same performance as the one achieved by the conventional federated learning with 444 sub-channels.

The MLP model converges slower compared to the CNN model. The conventional federated learning scheme achieves 96%percent9696\% accuracy in 981981981, 767767767, 528528528, and 445445445 rounds with 111, 222, 444, and 888 sub-channels, respectively. Similar to the results with the CNN model, introducing clustering into the federated learning setup decreases the number of required training rounds significantly. However, the PFL method provides little to no gain compared to the conventional federated learning scheme if the number of sub-channels is high, e.g., if the number of sub-channels is 888 in our simulation setup.

IV-B Federated EMNIST Dataset

In this section, we use the extended version of the MNIST dataset, namely, EMNIST [22]. We use the federated EMNIST dataset in which the data is already distributed to the clients by their writing styles. The EMNIST dataset has letters additionally; however, we will use only the digits dataset. The federated EMNIST digits dataset has a total of 341,873341873341,873 train and 40,8324083240,832 test samples distributed among 3,38333833,383 clients. There are 101010 classes in the dataset, each corresponding to a hand-written digit. The data distribution among the clients is shown in Fig. 4. As seen from Fig. 4, the distribution of the number of data samples among the clients is unbalanced and not uniform. We formulate the client clustering problem as shown in (23) for clustering the clients for the federated EMNIST dataset, and then we solve the problem efficiently using Algorithm 2. Accordingly, in the training step, we first cluster the clients using the proposed optimization problem. Then, we train the model using the PFL scheme. We performed the simulations for 111, 222, 333, and 444 clusters and 111, 222, 444, and 888 sub-channels, respectively. We used a two-layer CNN model with 323232 and 646464 5×5555\times 5 filters as the neural network model. The batch size is chosen as 161616, and the learning rate is optimized using a multiplicative parameter grid. The number of local epochs is chosen as 111 in order to assess the convergence speed. The required number of rounds to achieve 97%percent9797\% accuracy for the EMNIST digits dataset is given in Table IV.

The number of communication rounds required is 686686686 for the 111 sub-channel and 111 cluster case. The number of communication rounds drops by 64%percent6464\% to 274274274 rounds by introducing 111 additional cluster. The number of communication rounds gets lower and lower with the increasing number of clusters. The gain from the proposed PFL scheme decreases if the number of available sub-channels increases. Therefore, we could conclude that the proposed scheme may not be feasible if the number of sub-channels is sufficiently large, e.g., more than 444 sub-channels in this case. As seen from Table IV, the model converges faster for a higher number of clusters in the system. However, the marginal gain obtained by each additional cluster decreases with the number of clusters already present in the system.

IV-C Federated Shakespeare Dataset

For modeling time-series data, we used federated Shakespeare dataset [1, 23] for training a stacked two-layer long short-term memory (LSTM) network. Federated Shakespeare dataset is built by combining all works of Shakespeare. The dataset consists of the speaking roles of 715715715 characters in each play, corresponding to the clients in our federated learning setup. The dataset is unbalanced since most of the plays have a few lines, and a small number of clients have a high count of lines in their plays. Additionally, the number of data samples is not distributed uniformly to the clients. It is also clear that the dataset is not independent identically distributed (i.i.d.) since the dataset is distributed to the clients according to the played character. We use Algorithm 2 for determining the clusters for the clients. Then, we train the model using the proposed PFL scheme. The neural network model used for this task has an embedding layer at the input, which embeds the input characters into an 888 dimensional space. After the embedding layer, it has two LSTM layers with 256256256 hidden nodes. Finally, it has an output layer with softmax activation with an output for each character. In training, we set the batch size to be 101010 and optimized the learning rate through a multiplicative parameter grid. The simulation results for the application of PFL for the training of the two-layer LSTM network on the Shakespeare dataset are given in Table V. The rows represent the number of clusters, and the columns represent the number of sub-channels. The values are given in terms of the number of rounds required to reach 40%percent4040\% accuracy in the training. By examining the simulation results for both federated the EMNIST and the Shakespeare datasets, we conclude that the proposed pipelining scheme improves the results for non-uniformly distributed data more significantly.

V Conclusions

One of the main challenges of federated learning is the heterogeneity across the participating clients in terms of their computation duration and the size of the local data set. To mitigate this challenge, we have proposed using communication pipelining to enhance the spectrum utilization efficiency and speed up the convergence of federated learning. The main idea is to cluster clients based on their computation time and then schedule a balanced mixture of clients from the different clusters. The faster clients access the spectrum first, while the slower clients are still running their computation. By allowing more clients to be involved in each iteration, the time required to converge into a targeted prediction accuracy of the trained model can be reduced significantly. The time per iteration does not change in comparison with conventional federated learning. Nevertheless, the required number of iterations and the total time to train the model are reduced. We provided a generic formulation for the optimal client clustering under different settings and an efficient algorithm for obtaining the optimal solution. We demonstrated that the required number of communication rounds also depends on the number of sub-channels, and the gain obtained from the proposed method is lower for a high number of sub-channels.
